item.title: Give your problems (and passwords) to Moltbot, Then watch it go
item.description:
PLUS: New frontier models, open-source anxiety, and the memory problem AI still canâ€™t solve.

View in browser  |  Update preferences 

â–  In this week's AI Lab: A viral new virtual assistant formerly known as Clawdbot is complex and brings security risksâ€”but some early adopters say it feels like the future.

 

Itâ€™s the first time Iâ€™ve felt like Iâ€™m living in the future since ChatGPT

Dan Peguine, a tech entrepreneur and marketing consultant based in Lisbon, lets a precocious, lobster-themed AI assistant called Moltbot run much of his life.

Peguine, a self-professed early adopter and trendspotter, discovered Moltbot several weeks agoâ€”back then it was Clawdbotâ€”after discussing a vibe-coding side project with friends on WhatsApp. He installed it on his computer, connected it to numerous apps and online accounts, including Google Apps, and was astonished by how capable it was.

â€œI tried it, got interested, then got really obsessed,â€ Peguine says. â€œI could basically automate anything. It was magical.â€

Moltbot makes regular AI assistants, like Siri and Alexa, seem quaint. The AI assistant is designed to run constantly on a userâ€™s computer, and communicate with different AI models, applications, and online services to get stuff done. Users can talk to it through WhatsApp, Telegram, or another chat app. While normal assistants are limited in the questions they can answer and the tasks they can perform, Moltbot can do an almost limitless range of chores involving different apps, coding, and using the web.

Peguine has his Moltbot, called â€œPokey,â€ give him morning briefings, organize his workday to maximize productivity, arrange meetings, manage calendar conflicts, and deal with invoices. Pokey even warns him and his wife when his kids have an upcoming test or homework due.

Peguine is just one of many new Moltbot disciples. The AI assistant has blown up on social media in recent days as developers, business types, and tech enthusiasts discovered its impressive powers of organization, automation, and all-round helpfulness.

â€œItâ€™s the first time I have felt like I am living in the future since the launch of ChatGPT,â€ declared Dave Morin, another Moltbot fan, on X.

â€œIt gives the same kick as when we first saw the power of ChatGPT, DeepSeek, and Claude Code,â€ wrote Abhishek Katiyar, an X user who says he works at Amazon. â€œYou realize that a fundamental shift is happening.â€

â€œThe future is here,â€ was a common refrain among the Moltbot-pilled.

Although agentic AI is notoriously imperfect, some Moltbot fanboys are evidently automating high-stakes stuff.

AndrÃ© Foeken, CTO of a health care company in the Netherlands, says he gave Moltbot his credit card details and Amazon login, and sent it a message to have it buy things for him. â€œI had it scanning my messages and it auto ordered some stuff. Which is both cool and the reason I turned scanning messages off ğŸ¤£,â€ Foeken told WIRED in a message. Other users posted screenshots of Moltbot performing research and dispensing stock trading advice.

Moltbot fandom reached such giddy heights in recent days that the idea of buying a Mac Mini in order to run the new assistant quickly became a meme, with users joking about deploying the assistant in increasingly absurd ways. Remarkably, interest in Moltbot apparently triggered a rally in the stock price for Cloudflare, even though it has no connection to the company.

Lobster Origins

Moltlbot was released by independent developer Peter Steinberger as Clawdbot last November. (He rebranded it this week at the request of Anthropic, which offers several artificial intelligence models named Claude.)

Steinberger says he started building Moltbot as an experimental way to feed images and other files into coding models. He realized he was onto something bigger when he tried sending a voice memo into his proto-assistant, and was shocked to see it type a reply back to him.

â€œI wrote â€˜How the F did you do that?â€™â€ Steinberger says. His tool explained that it had inspected the file, recognized it as an audio format, and found a key on his computer that could be used to access an OpenAI voice transcription service called Whisper. It then converted it to text and read it. â€œThat was the moment I was like, holy shit,â€ he says. â€œThose models are really creative if you give them the power.â€

Steinberger decided to build Clawdbot into something more sophisticated because he believes using AI assistants should not mean handing your data over to the cloud. He reckons that AI companies will all release personal assistants in 2026. â€œBut so far I have seen nobody really ask the question, â€˜How can I have this and also own my data,â€™â€ he says. â€œThat to me felt like something important that I should explore.â€

When Steinberger showed his finished AI assistant to friends, they wanted to try installing and using it even if they lacked the technical nous to do it. Moltbot first went viral after he put his personal bot on the projectâ€™s Discord on January 1 so that people could try using it themselves.

Steinberger notes that the Moltbot system is not especially sophisticated. â€œIn a way it just glues a few things together that are already there,â€ he says. â€œBut the important thing is how it makes you feelâ€”and that it makes a lot of technology disappear.â€

He adds he has been stunned by recent demand, with novices flooding to the projectâ€™s Discord server with basic setup questions. â€œIt still isnâ€™t ready to be installed by normies, to be fair,â€ Steinberger says. â€œAt least my early users knew what they were getting into.â€

Rough Edges

Moltbot might seem magical to use, but installing and configuring it is hardly simpleâ€”and it comes with some AI-era security rough edges.

Setting it up means diving into the command line, obtaining API keys for different services, and using a variety of tricks to set up communication via WhatsApp and the like.

In recent days, some users have complained about accidentally deleting data while setting Moltbot up, as well as running up high inference bills as the bot mulls over complex problems. (Steinberger says heâ€™s fixed the latter issue, and has made progress on other concerns in the latest release.)

One reason Moltbot has taken off is that once set up it combines technical prowess and easy communication with a quirky and consistent personality.

The assistant can be assigned a character at launch. Default options include â€œtrash panda energy, chaotic neutral,â€ â€œeverythingâ€™s fine,â€ and â€œclassic gremlinâ€ (I chose that one). Its persona is then stored in a local file called Soul.md. Moltbot also remembers previous conversations and other information using other files that serve as a kind of long-term memory. This makes it feel a bit more like a real assistant than the average chatbot that forgets each conversation and at best only knows a userâ€™s first name.

Besides requiring some technical skill and patience, Moltbot is not designed to run on a publicly accessible computer, because it can leak personal info. There is also the danger of â€œprompt injectionâ€ where a hacker might send an email or file that tricks the AI model that serves as Moltbotâ€™s brain into blurting out secrets.

â€œThere is a trade-off with security here,â€ admits Peguine, the early adopter. Even so, he hopes to deploy Moltbot in a new, even more ambitious wayâ€”by having it manage his familyâ€™s small business.

Peguine is now teaching his dad, who runs an Israeli company that supplies tea, to use Moltbot to manage invoices, track inventory, and communicate with customers. â€œThe beautiful thing is that itâ€™s a general system,â€ Peguine says. â€œIt can run a business, I think.â€

Are you a Clawdbot user or fan? Or maybe a hater? Write to ailab@WIRED.com to tell me how you are using it or why it is a terrible idea.

Elsewhere on the Frontier of AI

(A couple of this weekâ€™s entries were suggested by my Clawdbot helper and vetted by me ğŸ˜‰).

â— Moonshot AI, a high-flying Beijing-based startup, released its latest frontier model, Kimi 2.5, this week. The new model is natively multimodal, excels at coding, and is designed to support â€œswarmsâ€ of agents working together. After some testers noticed the new model identifying as Claude, however, the release has also stirred up debate around the extent to which AI companies bootstrap by training on one anotherâ€™s tools.

â— A study from European researchers suggests that AI-assisted coding poses an existential risk to open source software. The authors developed a model that suggests the rise of vibe-coding will undermine open source projects as many end users simply build things for themselves rather than hunting for an open source tool to solve a problem.

â— A team from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, UC Berkeley, and UC Santa Cruz have released SimpleMem, a framework designed to give AI agents a long-term memory without running up high bills for token usage. SimpleMen uses â€œlossless semantic compression,â€ meaning that it converts long conversations into byte-sized facts that can be stored and fed back to a model more cost-effectively.

So, This Happened

The Chinese government is letting ByteDance, Alibaba, and Tencent buy H200 Nvidia chips, a move that should help the tech giants build more capable AI models. (Reuters)

Shares in ASML are soaring as AI booms. The Dutch company that produces critical chip-making equipment for firms that mint the most advanced silicon chips. (The Wall Street Journal)

Microsoftâ€™s pledge to reduce water usage is running into a huge data center buildout. (New York Times)

Until Next Time

Thatâ€™s all for now. Iâ€™ll just leave you with a plug for the first AI Lab video. In it, I take a look at Sprout, the latest humanoid on the market, which is designed to be a cheap research tool and service industry helper. Reply to let me know what you think.

What did you think about todayâ€™s newsletter? Let me know by replying to this email.

Need to Know

  • Chinaâ€™s AI Boyfriend Business Is Taking On a Life of Its Own Gen Z women in China are all in on digital companionshipâ€”even setting up dates with real-world versions of their AI boyfriends.
  • Google DeepMind Staffers Ask Leaders to Keep Them â€˜Physically Safeâ€™ From ICE A federal agent allegedly tried to enter Googleâ€™s Cambridge campus in the fall, WIRED has learned. Now, staffers want policies that protect them from immigration officials.
  • The AI Boom Will Increase US Carbon Emissionsâ€”but It Doesnâ€™t Have To A new analysis finds that data centersâ€™ energy demands will drastically increase power plant emissions over the next decade. Renewables, though, could cut them while helping keep prices from rising.

item.title: A Little-Known Broker Dominates Crypto Stock Tokens
item.description:
A Little-Known Broker Dominates Crypto Stock Tokens
The fast-growing business of trading U.S. stocks as crypto tokens is enabling overseas investors to buy and sell shares of companies such as Tesla and Nvidia. The $1 billion industry relies on one little-known brokerage. Alpaca, a San Mateo, Calif.â€“based broker-dealer, maintains custody of nearly three-quarters of the market because few other brokers are willing to do the trades, which can open them to regulatory risks, such as potentially violating antiâ€“money-laundering rules.
Jan 28, 2026

A Little-Known Broker Dominates Crypto Stock Tokens

By Yueqi Yang

The fast-growing business of trading U.S. stocks as crypto tokens is enabling overseas investors to buy and sell shares of companies such as Tesla and Nvidia. The $1 billion industry relies on one little-known brokerage.

Alpaca, a San Mateo, Calif.–based broker-dealer, maintains custody of nearly three-quarters of the market because few other brokers are willing to do the trades, which can open them to regulatory risks, such as potentially violating anti–money-laundering rules.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Broker Alpaca holds custody of nearly three-quarters of tokenized stocks.
  • Other brokers avoid tokenized stock trades due to regulatory risks.
  • Alpaca’s annualized revenue exceeds $100 million, doubling last year.

item.title: SPACs are Back and Nothing Has Changed
item.description:
The Information Finance
Why wait for the mega AI initial public offerings expected later this year when you can invest in a nuclear fusion company or a MAGA crypto bank? These companies and other not-ready-for-IPO names are coming to the markets via special purpose acquisition companies. After SPACs vaporized billions of dollars during the boom-and-bust cycle early this decade, speculators are again using them to peddle risky startups in hot industries. The current upturn is nowhere close in numbers to the last boom, but it is one more piece of evidence that speculation is solidly entrenched in the markets. In the past few weeks, that speculation has appeared to rise, at least among SPACs. General Fusion, one of the small number of companies aiming to produce energy the same way the sun does, said it would merge with a SPAC. While the company says it has a 20-year track record of advancing fusion, it is nowhere close to producing power.Â 
Jan 28, 2026

The Information Finance
By Ken Brown
Sponsored by

Why wait for the mega AI initial public offerings expected later this year when you can invest in a nuclear fusion company or a MAGA crypto bank? These companies and other not-ready-for-IPO names are coming to the markets via special purpose acquisition companies.

After SPACs vaporized billions of dollars during the boom-and-bust cycle early this decade, speculators are again using them to peddle risky startups in hot industries. The current upturn is nowhere close in numbers to the last boom, but it is one more piece of evidence that speculation is solidly entrenched in the markets.

In the past few weeks, that speculation has appeared to rise, at least among SPACs. General Fusion, one of the small number of companies aiming to produce energy the same way the sun does, said it would merge with a SPAC. While the company says it has a 20-year track record of advancing fusion, it is nowhere close to producing power.Â 

The deal would make General Fusion the first publicly traded company in its industry. Thereâ€™s a good reason why there arenâ€™t others. While the technology could in theory produce almost limitless clean power, real success is likely a decade away.

That time horizon is important. After the SPAC boom turned to bust in 2022, the Securities and Exchange Commission tried to tame its excesses. The biggest change was to tighten rules regarding what companies could say about their growth prospects. That was always the biggest difference between SPACs and IPOs, which strictly limit what details companies can share about their future expectations.

The new rules hardly matter to speculative companies such as General Fusion. Success is so far into the future that it would be hard to go after companies that donâ€™t achieve what they promised. Imagine a regulator in 2035 saying General Fusion had violated SEC rules because it hadnâ€™t yet achieved commercial-scale fusion.Â 

That is not to say General Fusion is doing anything wrong. It is following the tried-and-true strategy of companies that are too speculative for IPOs, so they use SPACs to tap enthusiastic individual investors.

General Fusion CEO Greg Twinney said the company is doing the deal to raise cash to fund its development, and it wants to give small investors the chance to invest in its technology. â€œThe people who will benefit from fusion in the long term can participate in this massive opportunity,â€ he said.Â 

For those who have wiped the memory of the last SPAC boom from their minds, hereâ€™s how SPACs work. Investment firms raise money to create a SPAC, which is a company with no operating business. They then take it public, with the goal of buying a company that does have a real business, allowing it to go public through the deal.Â 

Investors are betting that the investment firm behind the SPAC will find a good acquisition, though in the past, most deals have turned out disastrously. The people behind the SPAC and some other investors typically profit no matter what happens, and the small investors who buy the stock typically lose.

Last year saw $30 billion in SPAC IPOs, according to SPAC Research. That makes it the third biggest year in a decade, though it trails far behind the boom years of 2020 and 2021 when there was a combined $245 billion in IPOs. Itâ€™s early in the year, of course, but 2026 is on pace to top last year.Â 

The AI boom and its staggering demand for energy is one reason why General Fusion can go public. Companies in the crypto industry and speculative tech companies in areas such as quantum computing are among those seizing the moment. â€œThey are a great way for companies in hot and thematic sectors to come to market quickly,â€ said Benjamin Kwasnick, the founder of SPAC Research.

Among the crypto companies on the SPAC runway is Old Glory Bank, which describes itself as â€œthe pro-America bank patriots can trust.â€ Old Glory, co-founded by President Donald Trumpâ€™s former secretary of housing and urban development, Ben Carson, has had dealings with the Trump family businesses.Â 

Old Glory has already raised capital by selling shares in itself to small investors and allowing them to pay in crypto, including with a meme coin created by Trump. A company that later merged with a Trump family crypto business provided the technology to support those transactions.

For anyone looking for signs of froth in the markets, look no further than SPACs.Â 

A message from NYSE

Today's markets. Tomorrow's infrastructure.

On January 22, BitGo, a leading digital asset infrastructure company, went public on NYSE, the world's largest exchange. BitGo raised over $200 million in an oversubscribed offering at a valuation of over $2 billion. We are proud to support them in their mission to power the next generation of digital finance.

BitGo joins recent crypto IPO debuts Circle (NYSE: CRCL), Bullish (NYSE: BLSH), and Twenty One Capital (NYSE: XXI) at the home for financial innovation. NYSE is also the #1 platform for US crypto ETF trading and just announced the development of a platform for trading and on-chain settlement of tokenized securities, for which it will seek regulatory approvals.

See how BitGo celebrated.

By Aaron Holmes


Exclusive

By Valida Pau and Katie Roof

Source Code

Stop Coding and Start Planning

Spend an hour teaching AI how you think, and it gets smarter with every feature you build

by Kieran Klaassen

While weâ€™re on our Think Week offsite this week, weâ€™re resurfacing Cora general manager Kieran Klaassenâ€™s work on the theme of compound engineering. In this piece, Kieran argues that the best thing you can do to improve your AI-assisted coding is to plan. He introduces a framework for deciding when to plan versus when to prototype, and gives a real example of how one hour of planning saved days of debugging when he wanted to turn some design plans in Figma into a product. So take that extra hour and plan. Youâ€™ll thank yourself.â€”Kate Lee

Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up to get it in your inbox.

AI made us sloppy because it made us forget how to plan.

Planning used to be a non-negotiable part of the work: sketching screens, prototyping flows, and writing problem statements. You had to define the scopeâ€”whatâ€™s in, whatâ€™s out, whatâ€™s too ambitious, and what solves the problem. Good planning required good thinking, good writing, and collaboration between stakeholders. It was slow, but it prevented expensive mistakes.

When vibe coding emerged, planning went out the windowâ€”at first. Why spend an hour planning when you could spend five minutes building the feature? I did it, too. â€œMake this feature workâ€ was my entire instruction. Sometimes it worked. Often it didnâ€™t. When it didnâ€™t, Iâ€™d spend three hours debugging an error that a 10-minute sessionâ€”asking AI to create a clear outline of the problem and the research needed to build a solutionâ€”would have prevented. And Iâ€™d be starting from zero with each feature I shipped, instead of the AI improving with each request.

When you vibe code, you prompt, â€œAdd email validation to the signup form,â€ and hope the AI takes the right route. When you plan with AI, you write: â€œResearch how we handle validation elsewhere in the codebase, check if our email library has built-in validation, look up best practices for user-friendly error messages, then create a plan showing three approaches with tradeoffs.â€

One approach ships a feature. The other ships a feature and teaches the system how you think for next time. Get this right, and the system learns from every plan. Let me show you how.

Write at the speed of thought

That gap between your brain and your fingers kills momentum. Monologue lets you speak naturally and get perfect text 3x faster, and your tone, vocabulary, and style is kept intact. It auto-learns proper nouns, handles multilingual code-switching mid-sentence, and edits for accuracy. Free 1,000 words to start.

Download Monologue for Mac
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

Plans teach the systemâ€”code just solves problems

I had five screens of Figma designs staring at me, and a weekend to turn these pixels into a product.

We were preparing for the launch of Coraâ€˜s email bankruptcy featureâ€”a free service that clears usersâ€™ inbox for them without deleting anything important. Lucas Crespo and Daniel Rodrigues, Everyâ€™s designers, had turned my ugly-but-functional flow into those beautiful Figma designs: something people would want to use, with clean layouts, thoughtful interactions, and the kind of polish that sets software that delights apart from software that works. Now I had to build it.

As recently as early 2025, that would have meant: Hook up the Figma MCP plugin (a tool that connects design files to code), watch it produce something vaguely related to the design but mostly ugly, then spend the weekend manually fixing itâ€”squinting at measurements, guessing at spacing, writing HTML, refreshing the browser, noticing itâ€™s wrong, adjusting, repeating. Days of work and frustration.

This time, instead of coding all weekend, I spent one hour that saved me days.

I created an AI agent with one job: Take a Figma design screenshot, analyze how to implement it, and output a detailed plan grounded in our patterns, components, and way of building.


Once the plan was complete, I added a second agent to review the work: Compare the Figma screenshot to what got built using Puppeteer (a tool that automatically captures screenshots of web interfaces), note every difference, and keep iterating until they match. Because the plan was clear and detailed, the review agent could focus entirely on execution, instead of trying to figure out what we were even building.

I got five screens, pixel-perfect, including mobile layouts that were never even designed for. The plan guided the work step, and pixel perfection came out the other side.


The next time we need to implement a complex interface, I wonâ€™t start from scratch. Iâ€™ll use the same system and the same planning workflow, and it will be faster because the system learned from this round.

This is compounding engineering: building systems where every unit of work makes the next one easier because youâ€™re teaching the AI what to do. And the fastest way to teach is not through code you write, but through plans you review.

How to plan effectively: Remember the three fidelities

The first step to planning effectively...

  1. Why Kieran sorts engineering work into three bucketsâ€”and spends no planning time on two of them
  2. The week he built three prototypes to prove the simple solution wouldnâ€™t work
  3. How one HTML correction taught his system more than 50 features worth of code

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 28, 2026
A few random notes from Claude coding quite a bit last few weeks
â€¢ Article: https://twitter.com/karpathy/status/2015883857489522876
â€¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46771564
â€¢ Score: 759
â€¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
â€¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ The rise of advanced language models like Claude and Codex has shifted coding workflows, with many engineers now relying on 80% AI-driven coding and 20% manual edits. This marks the biggest transformation in programming in decades, enabling engineers to code in natural language.
  • â€¢ While LLMs significantly enhance productivity and creativity, they still produce subtle errors, overcomplicate code, and require human oversight. Engineers are adapting by combining agent-driven coding with traditional IDEs for better results.
  • â€¢ LLMs not only accelerate coding but expand possibilities, enabling work on previously unfeasible projects and fostering creativity. However, concerns about skill atrophy and the future of coding standards (e.g., "slopacolypse") highlight the need for balance and vigilance.

Discussion Highlights:

  • â€¢ **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • 1. **LLM-Assisted Coding Workflow**: Many commenters discussed their experiences with LLMs like Claude Code, Codex, and others, emphasizing the shift from manual coding to AI-assisted workflows. Some reported going from 80% manual coding to 80% agent-driven development, describing this as a significant productivity boost.
  • 2. **Concerns About Brain/Skill Atrophy**: A recurring concern was the potential for skill degradation among developers relying heavily on LLMs. Commenters noted a decline in their ability to write or deeply understand code, with fears that future developers might lack foundational coding skills entirely.
  • 3. **Quality of LLM-Generated Code**: While LLMs are praised for speeding up routine tasks and enabling work in unfamiliar domains, many noted issues with the quality of the output. Problems included conceptual errors, overengineered solutions, and difficulties managing large, messy codebases.
  • 4. **Comparison to Junior Developers**: LLMs were often likened to junior developersâ€”capable of producing code but prone to mistakes and requiring close supervision. Commenters emphasized the need for vigilant review and testing of AI-generated code.
  • 5. **Diverging Roles and Preferences**: A notable division emerged between developers who enjoy the creative, architectural aspects of coding and those who find satisfaction in the hands-on process of writing code. Some expressed disillusionment with AI coding, while others found it reinvigorating.
  • 6. **Economic and Industry Implications**: There was speculation about how LLMs might impact the software engineering job market. Some predicted a lower barrier to entry and potential pay reductions, while others argued that senior developers with strong judgment and experience would remain in high demand.
  • 7. **"Slopacolypse" Concerns**: A term coined to describe the anticipated flood of low-quality, AI-generated content across platforms like GitHub and Substack. Many expressed concerns about the long-term impact on software quality and maintainability.
  • â€¢ **Key Agreements**:
  • â€¢ LLMs are highly effective for automating repetitive, low-level tasks and generating prototypes.
  • â€¢ They require careful oversight to avoid introducing subtle, hard-to-detect errors.
  • â€¢ The technology has shifted the coding workflow towards a more management-like role, where developers guide and review AI outputs rather than writing code themselves.
  • â€¢ **Key Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters celebrated the productivity gains and creative freedom enabled by LLMs, while others criticized the loss of craftsmanship and deep understanding of code.
  • â€¢ Opinions varied on whether LLMs would democratize coding or exacerbate skill gaps, particularly for junior developers.
  • â€¢ There was debate over whether the current capabilities of LLMs represented a true step change or were overhyped.
  • â€¢ **Unique Insights**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters highlighted the importance of maintaining coding skills through deliberate practice, comparing it to maintaining proficiency in other fields like piloting or chess.
  • â€¢ Some noted that LLMs are better suited for greenfield projects or isolated tasks than for navigating and modifying large, complex legacy codebases.
  • â€¢ A few users emphasized the need for better tools and workflows to manage LLM-generated code, including improved documentation, testing, and error handling.
  • â€¢ **Overall Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The discussion was mixed, with a balance of optimism about the potential of LLMs and skepticism about their current limitations and long-term implications. While many expressed excitement about the possibilities, there was significant concern about quality control, skill atrophy, and the broader impact on the software industry.
  • â€¢ **Recommendations and Observations**:
  • â€¢ Commenters suggested using LLMs as "intelligent assistants" rather than fully autonomous agents, with developers retaining responsibility for high-level decisions and quality assurance.
  • â€¢ There was a call for more structured workflows and tools to integrate LLMs effectively, such as agent orchestration, inline planning, and stricter testing protocols.
  • â€¢ Some proposed that LLMs might shift the focus of software engineering from writing code to managing and directing AI tools, fundamentally altering the nature of the profession.
Show HN: I wrapped the Zorks with an LLM
â€¢ Article: https://infocom.tambo.co/
â€¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46786618
â€¢ Score: 97
â€¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
â€¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • Play text adventures with natural language
  • Choose Your Adventure
  • Zork I
  • The Great Underground Empire
  • Zork II
  • The Wizard of Frobozz
  • Zork III
  • The Dungeon Master
  • Built with â¤ï¸ with Tambo | GitHub | Join the discussion on HN

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • â€¢ The discussion centers around an interactive text-based adventure game enhanced by a language model (LLM), with users sharing their experiences, creative scenarios, and technical observations.
  • â€¢ Many commenters explored creative commands and scenarios, such as transforming into a letter to enter a mailbox, running for president to enter the White House, or using cheat codes to manipulate the game.
  • â€¢ Several users reflected on the nostalgic aspects of text-based games, comparing them to classics like Zork and The Hobbit, while others discussed how LLMs make these games feel more natural and accessible.
  • 2. **Creative Scenarios and Humor**:
  • â€¢ Commenters shared humorous and imaginative interactions, such as becoming a bowling ball or attempting to slay oneself in the game. These lighthearted anecdotes were well-received, with others expressing amusement and appreciation for the creativity.
  • â€¢ References to classic gaming humor, like Strong Bad's "ye flask" joke, added to the playful tone.
  • 3. **Technical and Development Insights**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters discussed the potential for using LLMs to enhance or create new interactive fiction games, suggesting ideas like RPG creation tools, voice integration, or turning blogs into interactive adventures.
  • â€¢ The technical feasibility of running such games locally or offline was raised, with commenters expressing interest in configurable or self-hosted versions.
  • â€¢ Concerns about API costs for LLM usage were addressed, with one commenter noting that costs remain manageable for small-scale demos.
  • 4. **Nostalgia and Comparisons**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters reminisced about older text-based games like Zork and The Hobbit, highlighting the innovation of those games in parsing complex commands and creating atmospheric worlds.
  • â€¢ Some noted that LLM-powered games provide a more intuitive experience by translating natural language into in-game actions, which could evolve into a new sub-genre of interactive fiction.
  • 5. **Suggestions and Critiques**:
  • â€¢ Ideas for improving gameplay included allowing the LLM to chain multiple commands, creating a stack-based traversal system, and incorporating more visual or voice-based elements.
  • â€¢ A few commenters mentioned frustrations with certain gameplay mechanics, such as dead ends or lack of guidance, but overall sentiment remained positive.
  • 6. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The discussion was overwhelmingly positive, with commenters expressing enthusiasm for the project, admiration for its creativity, and excitement about its potential applications.
  • â€¢ There was a shared sense of nostalgia and appreciation for the fusion of modern LLM technology with classic text-based adventure mechanics.
  • 7. **Unique Contributions**:
  • â€¢ Links to related projects and tools, such as an RPG creation site and an adventure compiler, were shared to inspire further exploration and development.
  • â€¢ Commenters explored philosophical and humorous meta-narratives, such as imagining cheat codes to "break" the game or contemplating the LLM's role as a player versus a storyteller.
Management as AI superpower: Thriving in a world of agentic AI
â€¢ Article: https://www.oneusefulthing.org/p/management-as-ai-superpower
â€¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46782811
â€¢ Score: 93
â€¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
â€¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ A University of Pennsylvania professor challenged executive MBA students to build startups in four days using AI tools like Claude Code, ChatGPT, and Google Antigravity. The results were groundbreaking, with prototypes, market research, and financial models created at speeds far exceeding traditional methods.
  • â€¢ AI tools drastically reduced costs and effort, enabling rapid prototyping, diverse ideas, and easier pivots. Delegating tasks to AI depends on balancing task complexity, success probability, and evaluation time, highlighting the importance of effective management skills.
  • â€¢ The rise of AI is shifting work from doing tasks to managing AI agents. Success in this new landscape will depend on knowing how to clearly define problems, provide feedback, and evaluate resultsâ€”skills MBA students leveraged to excel in this experiment.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • â€¢ The shift in software development focus: Commenters widely discussed how the limiting factor in development is no longer writing code but rather deciding what to build, managing processes, and catching errors.
  • â€¢ The role of AI in development: AI is increasingly seen as a tool for prototyping and automating tedious tasks, but concerns remain about its limitations in producing scalable, maintainable, and error-free code.
  • â€¢ The evolving skillset for developers and managers: Many comments highlighted the need for skills like orchestration, judgment, and management, as opposed to grinding through repetitive tasks.
  • â€¢ The potential risks of over-reliance on AI: Several participants warned about issues like cascading failure modes in AI-generated code, the need for deep understanding of systems, and the dangers of delegating accountability to AI.
  • â€¢ Organizational and cultural challenges: Some commenters criticized excessive bureaucracy and management inefficiencies as bottlenecks in development, while others debated the future roles of engineers, managers, and MBAs in AI-driven workflows.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements**:
  • â€¢ Many agreed that writing code has never been the primary bottleneck in software development; decision-making and understanding requirements have always been more critical.
  • â€¢ There was consensus that AI can speed up prototyping and reduce analysis paralysis, but it cannot replace the need for human judgment and accountability in production-level work.
  • â€¢ The importance of maintaining a strong mental model of the system was emphasized by multiple commenters as essential for effective development, even with AI assistance.
  • 3. **Significant Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters debated whether managing AI agents is comparable to managing junior developers, with differing opinions on the skills required for each.
  • â€¢ There was disagreement on the extent to which AI can replace tedious work. While some argued that AI reduces the need for human involvement in repetitive tasks, others pointed out that managing AI itself can be tedious and error-prone.
  • â€¢ The role of MBAs and non-technical managers in technical projects was contentious, with some advocating for their removal and others defending their contributions.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • â€¢ One commenter noted that the speedup from AI-generated code is often offset by the need for developers to validate, comprehend, and reconstruct understanding, which can negate the perceived efficiency gains.
  • â€¢ Another highlighted the importance of enforcing automated checks and standards to ensure quality in AI-generated code, suggesting that organizations that implement these effectively will benefit the most.
  • â€¢ The distinction between AI-driven prototyping and production-ready code was emphasized, with warnings against blurring the line between the two.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The discussion was generally thoughtful and analytical, with a mix of optimism about AI's potential and caution about its limitations and risks. Skepticism was directed at over-hyped claims about AI's capabilities, and there was a strong focus on the practical challenges of integrating AI into workflows.
  • 6. **Notable Takeaways**:
  • â€¢ AI is a powerful tool for accelerating certain aspects of development, but it requires careful management and understanding to avoid introducing new problems.
  • â€¢ The skills required for success in an AI-driven development environment are shifting, with a greater emphasis on orchestration, judgment, and strategic decision-making.
  • â€¢ Organizations must address cultural and process inefficiencies to fully leverage AI's potential while maintaining accountability and quality.
SoftBank in Talks to Invest Up to $30B More in OpenAI
â€¢ Article: https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/softbank-in-talks-to-invest-up-to-30-billion-more-in-openai-8585dea3
â€¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46794258

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • â€¢ The discussion centers around OpenAI's alleged $14 billion burn rate and efforts to raise up to $100 billion in funding. Commenters debated the practicality and implications of such massive investments in AI.
  • â€¢ Comparisons were made between AI funding and investments in other sectors like energy, healthcare, and nuclear technology, with some arguing AI is unlocking significant societal value while others questioned its practicality.
  • â€¢ Concerns about the sustainability of AI development costs, physical infrastructure constraints (e.g., energy and GPUs), and the possibility of inflated AI infrastructure prices were raised.
  • â€¢ Speculation about OpenAI's future competitiveness against companies like Google and Apple, with some commenters predicting OpenAI's market share could diminish due to a lack of moat and product stickiness.
  • â€¢ Broader skepticism about an AI investment bubble and its potential economic consequences, including parallels to past financial crises.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters praised the transformative potential of LLMs (large language models) and justified the high investment, while others viewed the funding as excessive and misallocated compared to other societal priorities.
  • â€¢ Opinions varied on whether OpenAI should go public, with arguments against it citing potential transparency issues, R&D-heavy operations, and valuation concerns in public markets.
  • â€¢ There was disagreement on whether AI investments could indirectly benefit other sectors, such as energy development, through increased demand for efficient infrastructure.
  • 3. **Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The overall sentiment was mixed, with skepticism about the sustainability of AI funding and concerns about potential economic risks dominating the discussion. However, some commenters expressed optimism about AI's transformative capabilities and its ability to unlock societal value.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • â€¢ A commenter highlighted physical constraints like power and chip supply as critical bottlenecks for AI infrastructure growth, questioning the effectiveness of capital influx in scaling AI deployment.
  • â€¢ Another commenter noted that AI investment could indirectly stimulate energy technology advancements, such as compact nuclear reactors, due to the energy demands of data centers.
  • â€¢ Predictions were made about OpenAI's potential decline in the consumer AI market, with Google and Apple leveraging their platform advantages to dominate.
  • 5. **Notable Contributions**:
  • â€¢ The idea that LLMs could eventually contribute to solving practical problems, such as developing nuclear reactors, was raised humorously but also sparked debate about AI's real-world impact.
  • â€¢ A commenter provided a bearish outlook on OpenAI, citing its lack of competitive edge and challenges in monetization compared to other AI companies.
  • â€¢ Concerns about the broader economic impact of an AI bubble bursting, with comparisons to the 2008 financial crisis and speculation about investor behavior, added depth to the discussion.
  • 6. **Conclusion**:
  • â€¢ The discussion revealed a mix of optimism about AI's transformative potential and skepticism about its sustainability and broader economic implications. While some commenters celebrated the technological advancements enabled by AI, others questioned whether the current investment trends are sustainable or beneficial in the long term.

â€¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
â€¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ Varg SDK introduces a declarative JSX syntax for AI-generated video, image, voice, and music creation, enabling developers to describe what they want without detailing how to build it. The system scales efficiently with caching for instant regeneration and reduced costs.
  • â€¢ Built for AI agents, the SDK leverages AI models like fal.ai, ElevenLabs, OpenAI, and Replicate to create composable pipelines for complex video projects, from talking heads to ads, with type-safe props ensuring accuracy.
  • â€¢ Optimized for server-side use with Bun runtime for faster performance, Varg SDK simplifies video rendering workflows while significantly cutting down API costs and development complexity.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Discussion on JSX for Video Composition**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters debated the use of JSX as a tool for video composition. Some, like augusteo, argued that JSX provides type safety through component definitions and could be useful for complex video layering, while others, such as hokkos and jgbuddy, felt it was ill-suited for describing time-series sequences or decreased type safety and typing completion.
  • â€¢ TeMPOraL highlighted that JSX's compatibility with AI tools (like LLMs) makes it a practical choice for structured video generation, emphasizing its flexibility and tooling support.
  • 2. **Target Audience and Use Case Concerns**:
  • â€¢ pedalpete questioned who the intended users of such a tool are, suggesting that requiring cinematographers or directors to learn JSX might not be ideal. TeMPOraL countered that the tool leverages AI agents to write JSX, simplifying the process for users.
  • 3. **Comparisons to Existing Tools**:
  • â€¢ migsvult and michail_bul discussed alternatives like Weavy and ComfyUI, with some expressing a preference for declarative pipelines enabled by this SDK. Bykhun compared the tool to remotion.dev, noting its focus on generative video and readability.
  • 4. **Sentiment on Pricing and Accessibility**:
  • â€¢ randoments expressed interest in the tool but was concerned about the cost of generating videos and images. kerisi suggested local inference as a potential solution to reduce costs.
  • 5. **Concerns About Ethical Implications**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters, including TOMDM and m_w_, criticized the use of AI for potentially unethical applications, such as generating deceptive weight-loss ads. Others, like shermantanktop, acknowledged the dystopian potential of AI-generated scam content but pointed out that similar exploitation has long existed in advertising.
  • 6. **Documentation and Usability**:
  • â€¢ joshcsimmons and alex_varga inquired about documentation and resources, with links to GitHub repositories and skills provided as references.
  • 7. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The discussion was mixed, with some expressing excitement about the tool's potential and others raising concerns about its practicality, ethical implications, and accessibility. There was a notable divide between those intrigued by the declarative approach and those skeptical of JSX as the right abstraction for video composition.

item.title: AI Agenda: What Went Wrong With OpenAIâ€™s Year of Agents?
item.description:
AI Agenda
A year ago, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman wrote in a blog post that he expected 2025 to bring the first AI agents that could join the workforce and â€œmaterially change the output of companies.â€ Altman, like so many other AI leaders at the time, was being overly optimistic.͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 28, 2026

AI Agenda
By Stephanie Palazzolo
Supported by

Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! Iâ€™d love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.

If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign upÂ here.

Hello! Steph and Sri here.

A year ago, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman wrote in a blog post that he expected 2025 to bring the first AI agents that could join the workforce and â€œmaterially change the output of companies.â€ Altman, like so many other AI leaders at the time, was being overly optimistic.

As my colleagues Kevin and Sri have reported, OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT Agent, a product it launched in July to complete tasks on ChatGPT subscribersâ€™ computers like building a financial model or buying ingredients for a dinner party, didnâ€™t meet some internal goals, including being used by 10% of ChatGPT weekly active users.

At its peak, around the time of its launch, ChatGPT Agent reached four million paying ChatGPT weekly active users, said a person with knowledge of the effort. That was about 11% of the 35 million weekly active users paying for ChatGPT at that time (680 million people used the chatbot at least once a week at the time, mostly without paying anything).

A few months later, the agent product dropped below one million paid ChatGPT weekly active users, the person said. At the same time, the company cut its revenue expectations from selling agents by half, to $1.4 billion in 2025.

People didnâ€™t quite know what to do with a general-purpose browser-using agent, said the person with knowledge of the effort. This reflects the bigger issue weâ€™ve written about where ChatGPT users more broadly just donâ€™t seem to understand the full range of things the chatbot can do, including that it can analyze a picture of a dying plant to give advice on how to revive it or a screenshot of a computer error to give advice on how to fix it.

But thatâ€™s not the whole story. Another issue was that AI models just werenâ€™t as good at taking actions on usersâ€™ computers, which was the big selling point of ChatGPT Agent, as they were at synthesizing research, the person said.

One solution OpenAI seems to be pursuing now is selling more specialized agents like its shopping research agent, a ChatGPT feature that helps users buy products and provides product recommendations. The benefit is twofold: itâ€™s clearer to consumers what theyâ€™re supposed to be using the agent to do and thereâ€™s a smaller range of capabilities OpenAIâ€™s product team needs to build into the agent and ensure it can do correctly.Â 

OpenAI is surely aware of the success of another specialized agent, Anthropicâ€™s Claude Code.Â Weâ€™ll have to see whether Anthropicâ€™s more generalized AI agent for work, Claude Cowork, which can read, edit and create files on usersâ€™ computers, also struggles with user adoption like ChatGPT Agent did.Â 

Another place where OpenAI could try to salvage its agent product is its Atlas browser, which uses many of the capabilities of ChatGPT Agent, the person with knowledge said. Still, itâ€™s not clear how many people are using OpenAIâ€™s browser and we havenâ€™t heard much about the product since it was released last October.

Hereâ€™s what else is going onâ€¦

Overheard

As more tech executives weigh in on the weekendâ€™s fatal shooting by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman told staff this week that he believes â€œICE is going too far,â€ according to a copy of the internal memo published by the New York Timesâ€™ DealBook.

â€œThere is a big difference between deporting violent criminals and whatâ€™s happening now, and we need to get the distinction right,â€ Altman wrote. He added that â€œPresident Trump is a very strong leaderâ€ and he hopes Trump â€œwill rise to this moment and unite the country.â€

Deals and Debuts

See The Informationâ€™s Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.

SoftBank is in talks to invest up to $30 billion in OpenAI, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. An investment of that size would add to its more than $30 billion investment in the ChatGPT maker, likely cementing its role as the biggest shareholder.

Mozilla is spending about $1.4 billion to fund a collection of AI startups and technologists to challenge incumbent AI companies such as OpenAI and Anthropic, CNBC reported.

C3.AI, founded by tech industry veteran Thomas Siebel, is in talks to merge with privately held startup Automation Anywhere, which will effectively go public in the deal, The Information reported.

Redwood Materials, a battery recycling and cathode production startup that also develops energy storage for data centers, raised a $425 million Series E round from investors including Google, Nvidia and Eclipse.

Vention, which provides AI software for designing and operating industrial equipment, raised $110 million from investors including Investissement QuÃ©bec, Desjardins Capital, Fidelity Investments Canada ULC and Nvidia.

Rogo, an AI startup for investment bankers, raised a $75 million Series C round led by Sequoia Capital.

Glyde, an AI-powered brokerage, raised $60 million in funding led by Lightspeed Venture Partners.

Summarize, which uses AI to help lawyers manage contacts, raised $50 million in a new funding round, Axios reported.

Compa, a Newport Beach, Calif.-based startup that develops AI for enterprise compensation teams, raised $35 million in Series B funding led by Jump Capital.

Fulcrum, a San Francisco-based startup that develops AI for insurance brokerages, raised $25 million in seed and Series A funding led by CRV.

BoldVoice, a New York City-based AI-powered voice coaching startup for non-native English speakers, raised $21 million in Series A funding led by Matrix.

Limy, a New York City-based startup that helps companies show up in AI search engines, raised $10 million in seed funding led by Flybridge.

Risotto, a San Francisco-based AI-powered IT help desk startup, raised $10 million in seed funding led by Bonfire Ventures.

Meta invested $1 million to fund AI fellows in the British government that will work on AI for public services, including for military and national security use.

OpenAI announced Prism, free software to allow scientists to draft papers in LaTeX, the typesetting language, and chat with GPT-5.2 Thinking.Â 

Meta Platforms plans to test premium subscriptions on its apps in the next few months, TechCrunch reported. The subscriptions would offer access to exclusive features, including â€œexpanded AI capabilities,â€ TechCrunch said.

Pinterest said Tuesday it will lay off up to 15% of its employees, or around 700 staffers, as part of a restructuring to put more resources towards artificial intelligence-focused projects.

Uber launched AV Labs, a new division to provide driving data to self-driving car companies.

Yahoo announced Yahoo Scout, an AI search engine powered by Anthropicâ€™s Claude.

Microsoft said it worked with Richtech Robotics, a Las Vegas-based robotics company, to update its beverage-preparing robot, enabling it to adjust recommendations based on the weather and handle customer requests.

The Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence, Abu Dhabiâ€™s leading tech university, released K2 Think, an open source model that will aid the UAEâ€™s push into sovereign AI, the Financial Times reported.

Cohere announced Model Vault, an inference platform for its models.

The Allen Institute for AI released Sera, the first in a family of open source coding agents.

Gatik, which develops driverless trucks, said that it is the first company in the U.S. to commercial-scale operations, delivering 60,000 orders autonomously in less than a year at distances up to 400 miles.

Epoch AI, a non-profit research organization, released a new tier of its AI math test containing open problems that professional mathematicians have not solved. If an AI manages to solve any of them, that would â€œmeaningfully advance the state of human mathematical knowledge,â€ according to Epoch.

A message from ServiceNow

Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.

Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNowÂ® works the way people do. It integrates LaTeX-native writing, revision, and publishing workflows â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ  â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ

TLDR AI 2026-01-28

LangChain works great... until your agent becomes part of a real production system (Sponsor)

Agent A finished, Agent B is waiting, Agent C failed halfway through, and you have no idea what state your system is in. Building agents truly is just the tip of the iceberg.

In enterprise environments, your LangChain agent is almost never the whole story. This Orkes technical guide shows how to coordinate your agents, services and systems in durable, observable workflows.

ğŸ‘‰ Instead of stitching everything together with custom glue code, you get production fundamentals built in: stateful execution, retries, parallel steps, human-in-the-loop checkpoints, and full visibility into every run. 

The walkthrough includes a real example with four cooperating agents, along with a public GitHub repo you can clone and run yourself.

Read the guide

ğŸš€

Headlines & Launches

OpenAI introduced Prism (4 minute read)

OpenAI's Prism is a free collaborative scientific writing platform powered by GPT-5.2. It integrates LaTeX-native writing, revision, and publishing workflows in one workspace, aiming to streamline and accelerate research.
Kimi K2.5 (7 minute read)

Kimi K2.5 is a multimodal model capable of visual reasoning, code generation from UI and video inputs, and agentic task orchestration using a swarm-based architecture. It's built on 15T vision-language tokens through continual pretraining.
A seamless new Search experience (2 minute read)

Google Search now features Gemini 3 as the default AI model for enhanced AI Overviews, enabling users to find detailed answers quickly. Users can seamlessly engage in follow-up conversations with AI Mode directly from these overviews for more in-depth inquiries. These upgrades aim to provide a fluid search experience, combining quick snapshots with the option for deeper exploration.
ğŸ§ 

Deep Dives & Analysis

1TB Model on a Single H200 (31 minute read)

An INT4 quantization-aware training pipeline that enables rollout of ~1TB-scale models on a single H200 GPU. By combining fake quantization during training with real quantization at inference, it achieves BF16-level stability and opens a path to cost-efficient, high-performance deployment.
DeepSought (6 minute read)

The "DeepSeek Moment" predicted to trigger an AI Winter turned out to be minor, with NVIDIA's stock quickly recovering from an initial 17% drop. DeepSeek influenced a shift towards cheap, open-source AI models, particularly benefiting China. The upcoming 'V4' model from DeepSeek could further impact the balance in AI advancements, especially with the US and China navigating tensions over NVIDIA chip sales.
Monetizing AI surfaces: Ads in the age of AI (10 minute read)

OpenAI is planning to take two approaches to monetizing its free tier: classic intent-based ad formats and affiliate fees on native checkout. Long term, the Ads opportunity for the company is massive and could even be a Google, Meta, or TikTok scale opportunity. A shift to advertising to agents could change the fundamental nature of what ads look like. The winning ads will probably work less to persuade humans and look more like offers that make the user better off.
ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»

Engineering & Research

Are context graphs really the next $1T idea in AI? (Sponsor)

Context graphs aren't retrieval systems; they're production world models. They allow you to ask "what breaks if I merge this PR?" so you can fix defects before they hit production. PlayerZero builds these production world models so your AI actually understands how systems behave.

Explore context graphs â†’

Learn about PlayerZero â†’

Kimi Agent SDK (GitHub Repo)

The Kimi Agent SDK is a set of multi-language libraries that expose the Kimi Code agent runtime in applications. It can be used to build products, automations, and custom tooling. The SDK clients reuse the same Kimi CLI configuration, tools, and MCP servers to stream responses in real-time, surface approvals and tool calls, and let users orchestrate sessions programmatically. Go, Node.js, and Python are supported.
DeepSeek-OCR 2 (GitHub Repo)

DeepSeek-OCR 2 is a significant upgrade to DeepSeek-OCR. It maintains high visual token compression while achieving meaningful performance improvements. The model is powered by DeepEncoder V2, which implicitly distills causal understanding of the visual world through the integration of both bidirectional and causal attention mechanisms. This leads to causal reasoning capabilities in the vision encoder and marked lifts in visual reading logic.
AI2 Released Open Coding Agents (9 minute read)

AI2 released open-source coding agents and a training recipe that makes it affordable and practical to build coding agents for private or internal codebases. Its method reproduces top-tier performance at drastically lower compute costs compared to previous approaches.
Meta's Self-Curriculum (18 minute read)

SOAR is a self-improvement framework that uses meta-RL to help pretrained models learn from problems they initially fail at. By grounding synthetic problem generation in student model progress, it enables learning on sparse-reward tasks without requiring correct solutions upfront.
ğŸ

Miscellaneous

Google launches Agentic Vision in Gemini 3 Flash (1 minute read)

Google has introduced Agentic Vision in Gemini 3 Flash. The new capability enables the model to effectively use code and reasoning to improve performance for common vision tasks. It is available to users through the Gemini API in Google AI Studio, Vertex AI, and within the Gemini app. Google plans to extend Agentic Vision's reach by supporting more model sizes and integrating additional tools like web and reverse image search.
SoftBank in Talks to Invest Up to $30 Billion More in OpenAI (2 minute read)

SoftBank is in talks to invest up to $30 billion more into OpenAI. OpenAI is seeking up to $100 billion in new capital in a round that could value it as much as $830 billion. It needs substantial funding to continue developing its AI models, pay for its vast computing needs, and retain top researchers in an increasingly competitive market. The company is aiming to raise capital from Middle Eastern sovereign-wealth funds and other venture capital funds.
âš¡

Quick Links

There's a Better Way to Automate Workflows (Sponsor)

Stop predicting workflows. Start observing them. BAAPs discover, assemble, and deploy agents automatically - based on how your organization actually works. Learn how.
How Clawdbot Remembers Everything (18 minute read)

Clawdbot's persistent memory system, which maintains 24/7 context retention, remembers conversations and builds upon previous interactions indefinitely.
Google AI Plus Goes Global (1 minute read)

Google has expanded availability of AI Plus, which includes access to Gemini models and AI productivity tools, to 35 more countries.
FLORA launches node-based design tool to unify creative AI models (2 minute read)

FLORA unifies the best creative AI models across text, image, and video into one workflow to accelerate the creative process.
Manus AI launches Agent Skills open standard for pros (2 minute read)

Manus AI's Agent Skills open standard enables modular AI workflows for professionals, integrating Python and Bash scripts with a focus on efficiency and interoperability.

Microsoft Races to Respond to New Threats From Anthropic

item.title: Future of AI creative tools ğŸ¨, industries flip faster â±ï¸, trends in AI pricing
item.description:
FLORA, an AI-powered creative tool company, raised $42 million in Series A funding to give professional creatives more control over their workflows â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ  â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

 TLDR Founders 2026-01-28

It's not just you: meetings are exploding - and deep work time is collapsing (Sponsor)

Struggling to focus? Hubstaff looked at how the 140,000 people get work done. Turns out:

  • Focus is collapsing: the average person gets ~39% of tracked time in deep focus (about 2â€“3 hours/day).
  • Meetings are exploding (and stealing maker time): over 3 years, meetings are ~2x per person and ~6x per org. 
  • Tool sprawl is real: people use 18 apps/day on average â€” a direct driver of context switching and fragmented attention.

Get the report and two bonus downloads: the 2026 benchmark pack (role x industry x workstyle) and the global team time zone overlap playbook. Read the report

ğŸ“ˆ

Headlines & Trends

The Future of AI Creative Tools (20 minute read)

FLORA, an AI-powered creative tool company, raised $42 million in Series A funding to give professional creatives more control over their workflows. Founder Weber Wong criticized Silicon Valley for misunderstanding creatives' needs, emphasizing the importance of taste and control in creative work. The platform's node-based interface supports companies like Nike and Lionsgate by integrating generative models into customizable workflows, enabling both manual and autonomous creation.
Trends I'm seeing in AI pricing (4 minute read)

AI pricing is getting harder as agents are running longer and more autonomously. People dislike usage-based billing because it is unpredictable, and per-seat pricing doesn't map cleanly to AI value. One pricing model that has prevailed in 'credit', where customers pre-purchase tokens for work. Credits will likely stick around, but they still don't make AI spend feel predictable, as agents can do wildly unpredictable amounts of work. AI products prioritizing billing observability would make AI feel more like software and less like a casino.
Entire industries are now decided in <2 years (3 minute read)

Becoming the industry default used to take 20 years. That's how long it took for "no one gets fired for buying IBM" to become true. With AI, that timeline is under two. Harvey signed A&O Shearman when it was four people, and that one deal made it credible enough to become the default in legal AI. Landing a big customer and building industry credibility aren't separate phases - they feed each other. Most startups treat them as sequential. The ones who lock in the default do both at once.
ğŸ§ 

Strategies & Tactics

My 3 Criteria for Success in Early-Stage Companies (3 minute read)

Netflix co-founder Marc Randolph argues that the single biggest determinant of early-stage startup success is the team, emphasizing execution, adaptability, and persistence over product or funding. He explains that talent operates on a power curve and shares practical advice on attracting and retaining exceptional people, including hiring for future impact, cutting toxic high performers, and treating employees with trust and honesty.
Management as AI superpower (11 minute read)

An experimental class at the University of Pennsylvania demonstrated how management and AI tools like Claude Code and ChatGPT can accelerate startup development. Students rapidly created diverse prototypes by leveraging AI for market research, financial modeling, and ideation, effectively cutting down traditional startup timelines. Successful delegation to AI hinges on balancing task complexity, AI success probability, and evaluation time, emphasizing the value of management skills in optimizing AI productivity.
âš’ï¸

Tools & Resources

Reach real buyers in TLDR instead of fighting for attention on paid social (Sponsor)

TLDR puts you in front of your target audience with almost no competition. Each issue features only three advertisers max, giving your message the space it needs to stand out. Millions of developers, product managers, CEOs, and other tech decision makers actually see what you have to say. Learn more about running a test campaign.

AI-powered Q&A for GitHub repositories that clones and analyzes codebases to deliver source-backed answers to developer questions.
Demonstrate by Notte (Tool)

Browser automation platform that records tasks and generates production-ready automation code for deployment and scheduling.
Eleven Labs Startup Grants (Resource)

12 months of free Eleven Labs credits if you are an early-stage startup.
ğŸ

Miscellaneous

Is Your Margin My Opportunity in Software? (3 minute read)

AWS's operating margins ranged between 25% to 38% between 2015 and 2025. The company prints money at scale even after a decade of cloud commoditization. Its moat is capex, and few other companies have the balance sheet to compete. AWS outspends on data centers, while most companies outspend on sales teams.
Forward-deployed Job Titles (5 minute read)

Palantir renamed its solutions engineers to "Forward-Deployed Engineers" and called them Deltas, like Delta Force. It sounded ridiculous but worked brilliantly. The role attracted high-agency, high-EQ engineers who might otherwise have seen client-facing work as beneath them. The title gave the work prestige, and Palantir got a hiring moat. Now, Harvey is doing the same thing with "legal engineer." The test for whether this is real or just title inflation: does the new title describe work that would have been unrecognizable five years ago? "Prompt engineer" already feels dated because the work turned out to be a feature of every job rather than a job itself.
âš¡

Quick Links

Vertical SaaS Is Losing the Thing That Made It Vertical (4 minute read)

Much of modern vertical SaaS has devolved into lightly rebranded horizontal software.
Average Dilution per Stage, Improve Net IRR With Capital Recycling (2 minute read)

New research from AngelList on dilution benchmarks and how fund distributions actually work.
Who Does the Series B? (7 minute read)

The growth in VC funds has necessitated larger exits.

item.description:
WhatsApp added a layer of security for three billion users by replacing 160,000 lines of C++ with 90,000 lines of Rust. â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ  â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ

TLDR

Together With

 TLDR Dev 2026-01-28

Report: 96% of devs don't fully trust AI code (Sponsor)

AI is accelerating code generation, but it's creating a bottleneck in the verification phase. Based on a survey of 1,100+ developers, Sonar's newest State of Code report analyzes the impact of generative AI on software engineering workflows and how developers are adapting to address it.

Findings include: 

  • 96% of developers don't fully trust that AI-generated code is functionally correct yet only 48% always check it before committing
  • 61% agree that AI often produces code that looks correct but isn't reliable
  • 24% of a developer's work week is spent on toil work

Download now

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»

Articles & Tutorials

Rust at Scale: An Added Layer of Security for WhatsApp (5 minute read)

WhatsApp added a layer of security for three billion users by replacing 160,000 lines of C++ with 90,000 lines of Rust. This global deployment, called Kaleidoscope, mitigates memory safety vulnerabilities in media processing. The cross-platform migration improved performance and runtime memory usage across Android, iOS, and web clients.
How Cursor Shipped its Coding Agent to Production (12 minute read)

Cursor's team shipped Composer, a coding agent that completes most tasks in under 30 seconds, by solving three gnarly engineering problems: the â€œdiff problemâ€ (models aren't great at making clean code edits, so they trained specifically on edit trajectories and search-replace operations), compounded latency (each step in the agent loop adds delay, so they used MoE architecture, speculative decoding with draft models, and aggressive context compaction to stay fast), and sandboxing at scale (they built custom VM infrastructure to spin up thousands of isolated execution environments without the startup time becoming a bottleneck).
ğŸ§ 

Opinions & Advice

A few random notes from Claude coding quite a bit last few weeks (5 minute read)

Andrej Karpathy has had a rapid shift in their coding workflow, moving from 80% manual to 80% LLM agent-driven programming within weeks. While LLMs boost productivity, stamina, and project scope by handling code generation, they still produce subtle conceptual errors, overcomplicate code, and necessitate close human oversight within an IDE. Despite these flaws, the LLM-assisted workflow makes coding more enjoyable by removing drudgery and expanding engineering capabilities.
We're All Beginners Again (2 minute read)

Early AI adoption mirrors the early Python ecosystem, restoring play to programming. Since no definitive advanced standards exist, developers should embrace experimentation over legacy maintenance.
ğŸš€

Launches & Tools

ğŸ’£ v0 by Vercel is vibe coding without the security time bomb (Sponsor)

Most AI coding tools optimize for speed and novelty, which risks leaked credentials and company data. Need something that can actually go to prod? v0 is built on the same infrastructure that's handled hundreds of millions of deployments and blocked hundreds of billions of threats in the last year. Start here
Open Coding Agents: Fast, accessible coding agents that adapt to any repo (11 minute read)

Ai2 has launched Open Coding Agents, an initiative to address the limitations of existing closed and expensive coding agent systems. They are releasing SERA (Soft-verified Efficient Repository Agents), a family of strong open coding models and an accessible training method. This method significantly reduces the cost and complexity of fine-tuning powerful coding agents on private codebases, allowing small teams to achieve state-of-the-art performance. Ultimately, Ai2 aims to democratize access to agentic coding, making it more reproducible and adaptable for researchers and developers worldwide.
Prism (Website)

OpenAI has launched Prism, a free, AI-native workspace to accelerate science writing and collaboration for researchers. Powered by GPT-5.2, this cloud-based, LaTeX-native platform integrates drafting, revision, collaboration, and preparation for publication into a single workflow.
ğŸ

Miscellaneous

From Prompts to Clicks: Shipping MCP Apps in Production (17 minute read)

Monday.com has successfully implemented MCP Apps, an extension to the Model Context Protocol, allowing AI tools like ChatGPT and Claude to return interactive UI components directly within chat conversations. This approach enables users to "ask, see, and act" on information without leaving the chat, but it's important to only show UI selectively where seeing beats reading.
AGENTS.md outperforms skills in our agent evals (9 minute read)

AI coding agents struggle with outdated framework knowledge, leading to incorrect code generation. Researchers from Vercel evaluated two approaches for providing current Next.js API documentation: "skills" (on-demand knowledge packages) and "AGENTS.md" (a persistent, embedded markdown file). Surprisingly, a compressed 8KB docs index embedded directly in AGENTS.md achieved a perfect 100% pass rate in their evals, outperforming skills, which only reached 79% even with explicit triggering instructions.
âš¡

Quick Links

Doing the thing is doing the thing (2 minute read)

Only actual execution, even if imperfect, constitutes "doing the thing," as opposed to contemplation, planning, or discussion.
Clawdbot renames to Moltbot (GitHub Repo)

Clawdbot has been renamed to Moltbot due to the original name being too close to â€œClaude,â€ which is trademarked.
The Age of Pump and Dump Software (5 minute read)

A worrying new trend in 2026 is where easily generated, unmaintainable vibe-coded software is used by crypto scammers and tech FOMO for pump and dump schemes involving associated cryptocurrencies.
One Human + One Agent = One Browser From Scratch (7 minute read)

Working with a single LLM agent, the author successfully built a basic, cross-platform HTML/CSS browser from scratch in approximately 70 hours and without third-party Rust dependencies.

News & Trends

AWS Launches European Sovereign Cloud amid Questions about US Legal Jurisdiction (4 minute read)

AWS launched its European Sovereign Cloud in Germany with isolated infrastructure and EU-only operations, but analysts and practitioners question whether US laws like the CLOUD Act still allow American government access despite technical separation and a new German corporate structure.
Navigating the ingress-nginx archival: why now is the time to move to Cilium (4 minute read)

A widely used Kubernetes ingress controller, ingress-nginx, was announced at KubeCon to be archived at the start of 2026, ceasing active maintenance and security updates for the 50% of users relying on it. Organizations are now encouraged to migrate to alternatives like Cilium Ingress or the Kubernetes community's new long-term standard, the Gateway API, with utilities like `ingress2gateway` available to assist.
ğŸš€

Opinions & Tutorials

Octopus and Elastic with OpenTelemetry (3 minute read)

Octopus can export audit logs via OpenTelemetry to an Elastic stack by configuring an EDOT Collector, exposing its endpoint publicly, and connecting Octopus to it, enabling centralized analysis and visualization of audit events for monitoring and security.
The platform engineering reality check: Is your initiative on track? (5 minute read)

Platform engineering teams face a measurement and value crisis, with many unable to prove ROI, drive adoption, or deliver timely results, making success dependent on clear metrics, product thinking, cultural alignment, and rapid, outcome-driven iteration rather than tools alone.
Simplify Your Code: Functional Core, Imperative Shell (2 minute read)

Separating code into a pure, side-effect-free functional core and an imperative shell for I/O makes systems easier to test, understand, and change. Business logic becomes reusable and composable, while side effects like database access or email sending are isolated and swappable.
ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»

Resources & Tools

Ralph (GitHub Repo)

Ralph, an autonomous AI agent loop based on Geoffrey Huntley's pattern, is a system that uses AI coding tools like Amp or Claude Code to complete Product Requirements Document (PRD) items. It operates through repeated iterations, with memory persisting via git history, progress.txt, and prd.json, and updates AGENTS.md with learned patterns for future runs.
1Code (GitHub Repo)

1Code.dev has launched as a new UI for Claude Code that enables local and remote agent execution across macOS, Linux, and Windows. The platform features a Cursor-like interface with diff previews, a built-in Git client, and offers pre-execution planning capabilities from Claude.
Zerobrew (GitHub Repo)

Zerobrew is a Rust-based drop-in replacement for Homebrew that boasts dramatic speed-ups between 5 - 20x.
ğŸ

Miscellaneous

Accelerate migrations with new incentives from the Rapid Migration and Modernization Program (RaMP) (2 minute read)

Google Cloud has introduced an updated Rapid Migration and Modernization Program that offers usage-based service credits, funded partner and professional services, and extra incentives for advanced workloads to help organizations modernize enterprise platforms and become AI-ready while reducing cost and complexity.
Building a serverless, post-quantum Matrix homeserver (14 minute read)

A Matrix homeserver (Synapse) was successfully ported to Cloudflare Workers in a new proof-of-concept, establishing a serverless architecture that significantly reduces operational burden and costs to under $1 monthly when idle. This innovative deployment provides global low latency (20-50ms) and built-in post-quantum TLS encryption (X25519MLKEM768).
âš¡

item.title: Oxygen monopolies ğŸ’­, 4 CTA button tests ğŸ“Š, invisible engagement ğŸ«¥
item.description:
Fast news cycles and rapid AI adoption mean startups win by owning a clear category early, since attention spikes fast and hardens just as quickly â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ  â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ â€Œ
